awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of high-resolution mass spectrometry system for metal-organic environmental and biological chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
Metals have a major impact on the health of the ocean, soils, and watersheds. Many metals are essential nutrients for life that often limit biological activity, while others are harmful contaminants from human activities. The biological uptake, toxicity, transport, and treatment of metals is largely controlled by molecules produced by microbes and plants that bind to these metals and keep them in solution. While it is widely recognized that many dissolved metals are mostly present as organic-bound forms in the environment, determining the composition, origin, and fate of metal-binding organic molecules is an analytical challenge due to the highly complex chemistry of environmental waters. The investigators in this study will acquire a liquid chromatography mass spectrometry instrument to enable new research on the origin and fate of organic molecules that govern metal distributions in the ocean, pathways for the microbial processing of metals, the reactions between metals and organic matter in soils, the design of improved water treatment systems that remove harmful metals associated with organic matter, and the development of machine learning approaches for environmental forensics. The instrument will also provide hands-on training of the next generation of environmental analysts through workshops and projects involving high school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students.

Low concentrations of iron and other micronutrient metals limit productivity across large sections of the ocean, but their chemical forms are largely unknown. This high resolving power mass spectrometry system will be used to separate and identify organic molecules and their isotopologues encountered in ocean waters. As part of the US GEOTRACES program, we will measure trace metal and organic speciation across the Southern Ocean and Antarctic shelf. This work will provide mechanistic insight into the processes that supply micronutrients to surface waters of the chronically metal limited Southern Ocean. We will also investigate the speciation of metals and organics sourced from coastal sediments, groundwater and microbial laboratory cultures to establish linkages between specific organisms/genes and metal binding metabolites that govern metal solubility and uptake across diverse environments. Furthermore, we will determine speciation of copper and other anthropogenic metals in river and wastewaters in order to assess toxicity and removal strategies. Another focus of our research will be to develop machine learning algorithms to develop markers of environmental processes based on high resolution mass spectrometry data. Such advancements have the potential to transform knowledge of elemental cycling from empirical descriptions to mechanistic models that better explain and predict environmental processes by accounting for chemical and biological diversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The environmental impact, toxicity, transport, and treatment of metals and pollutants in water are intricately tied to interactions between metals and organics. Thus, an improved understanding of the chemical form of metals in freshwater and marine systems has direct implications for the protection of environmental and human health. One of the main limiting factors in studying these metal-organic interactions is characterization of the sources, reactivities, and identity of organic molecules that bind to metals. Determining the composition of metal binding organic molecules in environmental and biological samples is an analytical challenge due to the highly complex mixture present in the environment.

Through this award, we acquired an ultrahigh pressure liquid chromatography - high field Orbitrap electrospray ionization mass spectrometry system (UPLC Orbitrap IQ-X MS) dedicated to the separation and sensitive detection and characterization of organic forms of carbon, nutrients, metals, and other elements these complex mixtures. This instrument was installed in the W.M. Keck Collaboratory, a mass spectrometry user facility that has operated at Oregon State University (OSU) since 1992 that supports research in earth, ocean, environmental, and biological sciences. This acquisition has enabled new research on the origin and fate of organic ligands that govern metal cycling in the ocean, pathways for the microbial metabolism and uptake of metals, the reactions between metals and organic molecules that stabilize soil organic matter, the design of improved water treatment systems that remove harmful metals associated with organic matter, and the development of novel approaches for environmental forensics and source tracking. Such advancements have the potential to transform knowledge of elemental cycling from empirical descriptions to mechanistic models that better explain/predict environmental processes by accounting for molecular speciation and connections between chemical and biological diversity.

The instrumentation has been used to train students in advanced analytical methodologies. Six graduate students and two postdoctoral scholars at OSU were trained in sample processing and instrumentation operation, and participated weekly workshops to learn about the instrumentation and the fundamentals of data processing workflows. Hands-on experience and training was also provided to high school and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups in STEM. Four undergraduate summer students operated and acquired data from the instrument, High school students participating in the OSU Summer Experience in Science and Engineering for Youth summer camp used the instrument for projects related to determining the sources of micronutrient metals in the Southern Ocean and determining how soil-derived metal binding molecules can selectively bind and separate metals. The instrument also supported the research programs of facility users, with research outcomes that will inform models of biogeochemical carbon and metal cycling, track sources and fates of environmental pollution, and guide the development of more efficient water treatment technologies.
